text: Pinchon's casePinchon's case (1611) 9 Rep. 86 was an early court case and precedent in assumptsit. Pinchons case established that contractual liability was transmittable to an estate if the debtor had died. However, the court also held that collateral promises did die with the debtor. This decision was over turned in Sanders v Easterby.Sanders v Easterby(1616) Cro Jac 417See also Smale v Boyer(1616)3 Blst248. when the court held that executors could be held liable for debts.Alfred William Brian Simpson, A History of the Common Law of Contract, Volume 1 (Clarendon Press, 1987) p572. ==See also== *Actio personalis moritur cum persona ==References== Category:English property case law Category:Court of King's Bench (England) cases Category:1611 in law Category:Edward Coke cases Category:1611 in England
